home_page.title: Welcom to {product_name}!
home_page.you_can_learn: At this site, you can learn about...

gate.title: Logic Gates
gate.subtitle: The fundamental units of digital circuits, controlling signal flow and performing basic logic operations.
gate.content: In this section, you can explore the working principles of common logic gates such as AND, OR, NOT, NAND, NOR, XOR and XNOR.

flip_flop.title: Flip-Flops
flip_flop.subtitle: The core elements of sequential circuits, used for storing and controlling signal states.
flip_flop.content: This section showcases various flip-flops (e.g., RS, D, JK, T) and their state transition rules, as well as their applications in circuits.

digital_circuit.title: Digital Circuits
digital_circuit.subtitle: A combination of logic gates and flip-flops that enables precise signal transmission and complex functionality.
digital_circuit.content: This section introduces components like registers and counters, explaining their roles in circuit design.

cpu.title: CPU Execution Process
cpu.subtitle: The pinnacle of digital circuits, performing instruction execution through logic operations and signal coordination.
cpu.content: This section simulates the CPU architecture and key processes such as fetch, decode, execute, and store, highlighting its internal collaboration mechanisms.

home_page.disclaimer: Some images and texts on this website are generated by AI and are intended for educational and reference purposes only. Please understand that there may be inaccuracies, and actual conditions should take precedence.

menu_beginning.title: The Beginning
menu_beginning.claude_shannon: A Symbolic Analysis of Relay and Switching Circuits

switches_page.title: Switch
switches_page.explain: The world of computers is actually quite simple. It only recognizes two numbers: 0 and 1, much like the two opposing ideas in philosophy - 1 represents 'yes', and 0 represents 'no'. In terms of the underlying structure of a computer, 0 means the switch is off, and 1 means the switch is on.

claude_shannon_page.title: A Symbolic Analysis of Relay and Switching Circuits
claude_shannon_page.source_tip: This image is from Claude Shannon's Wikipedia page
claude_shannon_page.introduce: If we want a computer to perform calculations, we need to establish logical relationships through switching circuits. The connection between switching circuits and logic was first established by Claude Elwood Shannon (hereafter referred to as 'Shannon'). In 1937, in his master's thesis at MIT, Shannon concluded that electronic switches could be connected in various ways to perform any logical function. This is considered one of the most influential master's theses in history. In his thesis, Shannon demonstrated that switches could be combined in different ways to execute simple logical operations, and these combinations of switches are called logic gates. The most basic logic gates that make up a computer are AND, OR, and NOT gates. Let's now take a closer look at these logic gates...

and_gate_page.title: AND Gate
and_gate_page.explain: An AND gate refers to connecting two switches in series, where the output will be 1 only when both switches are turned on. If either switch is off, the output will be 0. This logical relationship is represented by the following truth table:

or_gate_page.title: OR Gate
or_gate_page.explain: An OR gate refers to connecting two switches in parallel, where the output will be 1 as long as at least one switch is turned on. The output will only be 0 when both switches are off. This logical relationship is represented by the following truth table:

recommend_aspect_ratio_dialog.title: Sorry...
recommend_aspect_ratio_dialog.content:
The current screen resolution ratio of your device may affect the display quality of this page.
For the best experience, please ensure your screen resolution ratio is greater than 4:3.

Here are some suggestions to resolve the issue:
1. Use a larger device: If you're on a small mobile device, consider switching to a computer or a larger tablet for an improved viewing experience.
2. Adjust foldable devices: If you're using a foldable device, try unfolding it to increase the screen size.
3. Rotate your tablet: For tablet users, disable screen rotation lock and switch to landscape mode for optimal display.
4. Check your computer or laptop: If you're using a laptop or desktop computer and still seeing this message, congratulations! You may have unlocked some hidden “skill.” We recommend using the project as intended for the best results.

If you'd like to report an issue or provide feedback, feel free to submit an Issue on the project's GitHub page. We'll address it as soon as possible.
